title: Bronwyn Bishop to repay helicopter expense claim
text:
Bronwyn Bishop: "Whilst my understanding is that this travel was conducted within the rules, to avoid any doubt I will reimburse the costs." Share on twitter Share on Google Plus by Primrose Riordan Speaker Bronwyn Bishop has been forced to repay her expense claim for a $5000 chartered helicopter flight to a Liberal fundraiser, with a 25 per cent loading, after she was hung out to dry by her colleagues and pressured by Prime Minister Tony Abbott.
Senior Liberal ministers declined to support Ms Bishop claiming it as an entitlement, with Treasurer Joe Hockey even saying it did not "pass the sniff test" and he "understood" public anger over the issue.
She was also spoken to by Mr Abbott or his office to put an end to the damaging saga, sources said.
Ms Bishop came under fire this week for claiming $5227.27 for a chartered return helicopter flight from Melbourne to Geelong for a Liberal Party function in November, even though the 100-kilometre trip takes only 50 minutes by car.
She has also been criticised for spending more than $300,000 on overseas travel last year , including $90,000 on a trip to Europe trip, which she used partly to campaign for a new job.
While Ms Bishop did commit to sending the money back to the Department of Finance, she refused to back down from her assertion the claim was within her entitlements as Speaker of the House, saying she was simply repaying the money to remove others' doubts.
"Whilst my understanding is that this travel was conducted within the rules, to avoid any doubt I will reimburse the costs," she said.
She will follow new rules set out in yet-to-be-passed legislation , requiring MPs to pay an extra 25 per cent penalty loading on any incorrect travel claims.
 Earlier, Mr Hockey distanced himself from the Speaker, saying he could understand public anger over the chartered flight and that Ms Bishop would "need to explain" the use of the funds.
He said the claim was "not a good look" in the midst of federal budget trouble and Ms Bishop should "explain how the money was spent".
When asked whether it passed the "sniff test", he said "instinctively it doesn't".
Labor also called on Ms Bishop to pay back the funds, saying it was an "egregious abuse of entitlements".
"When you are too arrogant to drive in a taxpayer-funded car and instead you want a taxpayer-funded helicopter to fly above the people from Melbourne to Geelong to go to a state Liberal Party fundraiser," Opposition Leader Bill Shorten said.
Ms Bishop's office initially defended the expenditure on Wednesday, telling the Herald Sun the charter allowed her to attend as many meetings and events as she can in "concern for the country" and was in accordance with guidelines.
Labor waste watch spokesman Pat Conroy said the defence was "extraordinary" and"ridiculous".
